fields.headline: Bernstein bullish in backing Royle
fields.bodyText: Manchester City's chairman David Bernstein is determined to keep his nerve and stick with Joe Royle as manager. The pressure is beginning to mount on Royle after one Premiership win in their last 13 games. But Bernstein insists Royle's future is not in doubt. "I've made it clear from the beginning that stability and a long-term strategy are vital if this club is to progress," he told the Manchester Evening News. "For a whole range of reasons Joe is the right man for us. The toughest decision is to do nothing because people perceive that as being weak, but it's very easy to have a knee-jerk reaction." Royle, meanwhile, is confident City can get out of trouble. He said: "We have 15 games to put it right. I don't think we are one of the worst teams in the division, although our league position says we are." A busy day of transfer activity at West Ham saw Harry Redknapp complete the signings of the defenders Christian Dailly and Ragnvald Soma and bring in the right wing-back Sebastian Schemmel from Metz until the end of the season. Dailly arrived from Blackburn for £1.75m on a 3-year contract saying he was "angry and upset" at his treatment by Graeme Souness at Ewood Park. "It was always the case that I was going to be one of those he wanted to get off the wage bill," he told West Ham's official website. The 27-year-old will make his debut at Charlton on Monday but Soma, a Norway Under-21 international who cost £800,000 from Bryne rising to a possible £2m, is not expected to feature at once. Schemmel, 25, has been brought in as cover for Steve Lomas and Trevor Sinclair, who are troubled by knee injuries, with a view to a permanent transfer. Sinclair is to see another specialist to determine whether he needs an operation. Meanwhile West Ham's defender Javier Margas has retired because of a persistent knee problem. The 31-year-old returns to Chile to concentrate on his hotel business, promising that "any West Ham fans coming over can stay for free". West Brom are poised to sign the midfielder Michael Appleton from Preston for £750,000, subject to a medical.  You've read the piece, now have your say.
